name: Base Deck
description: The standard card set available to all players from the start.

cards.name: DNA Analysis
cards.description: The cold language of genetics speaks louder than any witness. When the DNA matches, denials crumble.
cards.effectDescription: Strong jury impact (+8). Reduces witness composure by 15 when presented during cross-examination.

cards.name: Security Footage
cards.description: The camera doesn't lie — but it doesn't always tell the whole truth either. What it captures depends on the angle.
cards.effectDescription: Moderate jury impact (+4). May reveal a witness lie if the footage contradicts their testimony.

cards.name: Financial Records
cards.description: Follow the money. Bank statements, wire transfers, and ledgers tell stories that people try very hard to hide.
cards.effectDescription: Moderate jury impact (+4). Extra effective in fraud and financial motive cases.

cards.name: Phone Records
cards.description: Call logs, text messages, and cell tower pings paint a timeline that's hard to dispute.
cards.effectDescription: Moderate jury impact (+3). Useful for establishing timelines and contradicting alibis.

cards.name: Expert Testimony
cards.description: When a recognized authority explains the science, even the most skeptical jurors take notice.
cards.effectDescription: Strong jury impact (+6). Grants +3 CP from demonstrated expertise.

cards.name: Eyewitness Identification
cards.description: "I'll never forget that face." Powerful words — but memory is a fragile thing.
cards.effectDescription: Moderate jury impact (+3). Slightly pressures the identified individual.

cards.name: Physical Evidence
cards.description: The murder weapon. The bloody glove. The torn fabric. Objects carry the weight of truth when words fail.
cards.effectDescription: Solid jury impact (+5). Physical evidence is trusted by analytical jurors.

cards.name: Digital Forensics
cards.description: Deleted files, browser history, metadata. The digital world remembers what people try to forget.
cards.effectDescription: Strong jury impact (+6). Can reveal hidden information or contradict testimony.

cards.name: Character Reference
cards.description: "I've known them for twenty years and they would never..." Character speaks when evidence whispers.
cards.effectDescription: Mild jury impact (+2). More effective with emotional jurors.

cards.name: Medical Records
cards.description: Hospital visits, treatment records, and injury reports. The body keeps score even when the mind tries to forget.
cards.effectDescription: Solid jury impact (+5). Can undermine witness claims about injuries, timing, or physical condition.

cards.name: Objection: Hearsay
cards.description: "Objection, Your Honor — hearsay!" The witness is repeating what someone else said, not what they personally observed.
cards.effectDescription: If sustained: blocks testimony, reverses jury impact (-2 from opponent). If overruled: lose 1 extra CP.

cards.name: Objection: Relevance
cards.description: "Objection — relevance?" This line of questioning has nothing to do with the matter at hand.
cards.effectDescription: If sustained: blocks testimony/evidence, partial jury opinion reversal. If overruled: lose 1 extra CP.

cards.name: Objection: Leading the Witness
cards.description: "Objection — leading!" Counsel is putting words in the witness's mouth during direct examination.
cards.effectDescription: Low cost objection. Only valid during direct examination. If sustained: question stricken.

cards.name: Objection: Speculation
cards.description: "Objection — calls for speculation!" The witness is being asked to guess rather than testify to what they know.
cards.effectDescription: If sustained: answer stricken, minor jury correction. If overruled: lose 1 extra CP.

cards.name: Objection: Lack of Foundation
cards.description: "Objection — no foundation!" Counsel hasn't established that the witness has personal knowledge or that the evidence is authentic.
cards.effectDescription: If sustained: blocks evidence card or testimony. Forces opponent to establish foundation first.

cards.name: Objection: Prejudicial
cards.description: "Objection! More prejudicial than probative, Your Honor." This evidence may be technically relevant, but its emotional impact far outweighs its factual value.
cards.effectDescription: If sustained: evidence excluded, significant jury opinion reversal (-4), judge appreciates proper legal argument (+2). High risk if overruled.

cards.name: Objection: Asked and Answered
cards.description: "Objection — asked and answered!" Counsel is repeating the same question hoping for a different answer.
cards.effectDescription: Low cost. If sustained: forces opponent to move on. Shows judge you're paying attention.

cards.name: Objection: Narrative
cards.description: "Objection — the witness is narrating!" The witness is giving a speech instead of answering the specific question asked.
cards.effectDescription: If sustained: witness is instructed to answer only what's asked. Limits opponent's control of testimony.

cards.name: Request Recess
cards.description: "Your Honor, the defense requests a brief recess." Sometimes stepping back is the best step forward.
cards.effectDescription: Draw 2 additional cards. Costs 2 CP. Resets jury engagement slightly. Judge may deny if patience is low.

cards.name: Approach the Bench
cards.description: "May I approach the bench, Your Honor?" A private word with the judge, away from the jury's ears.
cards.effectDescription: Private sidebar with judge. Can influence judge disposition (+3) and reveal judge's current leanings.

cards.name: Move to Strike
cards.description: "Your Honor, I move to strike that testimony from the record." Words spoken can't be unheard, but they can be officially ignored.
cards.effectDescription: If granted: removes last testimony from record, partial jury opinion reversal (-3). Judge instructs jury to disregard.

cards.name: Redirect Examination
cards.description: "Just a few more questions on redirect, Your Honor." Repair the damage, reinforce the message.
cards.effectDescription: Allows re-examination of your witness after cross. Restores some composure (+10) and reinforces testimony (+3 jury).

cards.name: Sidebar Conference
cards.description: Both attorneys approach. The jury strains to hear but catches nothing. Deals are made and lines are drawn at sidebar.
cards.effectDescription: Private conference. Can block opponent's next card play and reveal judge's stance on an issue.

cards.name: Motion to Dismiss
cards.description: "Your Honor, the defense moves for a directed verdict of acquittal." A bold play — if the prosecution hasn't met its burden, why continue?
cards.effectDescription: If granted: case dismissed, instant win. If denied: significant judge displeasure. Only effective when prosecution case is genuinely weak.

cards.name: Impeach Witness
cards.description: "Isn't it true that you previously stated..." Catch them in a contradiction and watch credibility crumble.
cards.effectDescription: Requires prior contradicting evidence. Major composure damage (-20), jury impact (+4), and CP gain (+2) from effective lawyering.

cards.name: Enter Evidence into Record
cards.description: "Your Honor, we'd like to enter this as Exhibit A." Making it official gives evidence extra weight.
cards.effectDescription: Formally enters evidence. Small direct impact (+1) but enables combo bonuses with other evidence cards (+2).

cards.name: Poll the Jury
cards.description: A rare glimpse behind the curtain. Request individual polling and read their faces as they answer.
cards.effectDescription: Reveals current opinion trends for 3 random jurors. Expensive but invaluable for strategy adjustment.

cards.name: Mistrial Motion
cards.description: "Your Honor, we move for a mistrial!" The nuclear option. If something has gone fundamentally wrong, blow it all up and start over.
cards.effectDescription: If granted: trial ends, case retried with new jury. If denied: massive judge displeasure and CP loss. Only viable with serious procedural violations.
